entry.summary:

The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Southern Natchitoches Parish in northwestern Louisiana... Northeastern Sabine Parish in northwestern Louisiana...
* Until 1145 AM CST.
* At 1056 AM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Many, or 20 miles north of Anacoco, moving east at 40 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Damage to vehicles is expected.
* Locations impacted include... Natchitoches, Many, Florien, Provencal, Natchez, Fisher, Robeline, Cloutierville, Melrose, Grand Ecore, Mount Carmel, Bellwood, Chopin, Flora, Cypress, Bermuda, and Hagewood.
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 8 at 11:54AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Ocmulgee River near Macon affecting Monroe, Bibb, Jones, Twiggs and Houston Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding will continue.
* WHERE...Ocmulgee River near Macon.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 25 feet, Minor flooding expands further into the woodlands and over the Macon GreenWay Ocmulgee Heritage Trail north of the Martin Luther King Boulevard bridge. The flood waters will be up to 5 feet deep on portions of the trail. Large portions of agricultural lands just east and south of Macon will be under 1 to 7 feet of water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM EST Friday the stage was 22.9 feet and slowly falling. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to around 21 feet tonight, then rise to a crest of 25.3 feet Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 18 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bibb, GA; Houston, GA; Jones, GA; Monroe, GA; Twiggs, GA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 9 at 2:53AM ChST until March 13 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to 13 ft. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk around Sunday through Tuesday and will be along shores exposed to the northeast and east swell across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher there. Moderate coastal inundation is possible if surf is higher than currently forecasted. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST WEDNESDAY... ...COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 8 at 11:43AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Georgia...
Oconee River near Oconee affecting Johnson, Wilkinson and Washington Counties.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Oconee River near Oconee.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 23 feet, Moderate flooding continues. Portions of the Old Balls Ferry Road leading to the boat ramp becomes flooded with a foot of water or more. The entire dirt parking lot near the boat ramp is under three to five feet of water. Extensive flooding of the woodlands near the river continues.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM EST Friday the stage was 15.5 feet and rising. - Forecast...The river will fall to 15.1 feet this afternoon. It will then rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to 24.8 feet Sunday morning. It will fall to 22.9 feet early Monday afternoon. It will then rise to 23.1 feet early Tuesday morning. It will fall to 22.7 feet Tuesday evening then rise again. - Flood stage is 17 feet.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 8 at 9:47AM CST until March 8 at 12:45PM CST by NWS Jackson MS
entry.summary:
FFWJAN
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Hinds County in central Mississippi... Rankin County in central Mississippi...
* Until 1245 PM CST.
* At 947 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 8:58AM CST by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
Surface reports indicate that a light frozen mix including light snow, some very light freezing rain or drizzle along with light rain is occurring over the area this morning. Though roads have generally remain in good winter driving condition with road temperatures above the freezing mark, a few slick spots may still develop this morning on bridges or overpasses or less traveled roads.
Please remain cautious while traveling this morning. Widespread impacts are not anticipated, but even small patches of ice can cause major challenges for motorists.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 8 at 5:34AM AKST until March 9 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW FOR HAINES HIGHWAY AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS...
.Heavy snow is falling in the Haines and Haines Highway area. Warm moisture will overrun cooler air at the surface, producing heavy snow and raising snow levels over time. As the warm air moves over Haines, snow will become increasingly wet and heavy, limiting snow totals. For areas 600 feet and above, such as Haines Customs, precipitation is expected to stay as snow and accumulate up to 12 inches.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 12 inches.
* WHERE...Haines Highway above 600 ft.
* WHEN...Until midnight AKST Friday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult and is discouraged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest snowfall rates around Haines Customs is expected to be Friday morning with rates around 0.5 to 0.75 inches per hour.

.Heavy rainfall is expected in the next 24 hours over the Tallapoosa River Basin basin and a flood warning is now in effect for the Tallapoosa River Basin.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Tallapoosa River at The Tallapoosa Water Plant.

At 10.0 feet, In Rutland, flooding will occur on low lying roads including Dorr Drive, Park Street and Clement Road. High water will also approach Meadow Street and the adjacent recreation fields will flood. Alfrecha Road in Clarendon will flood. entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 8 at 4:42AM CST until March 9 at 3:00PM CST by NWS Birmingham AL
entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding is expected to arrive as late this morning and may persist through early Saturday afternoon. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 5 inches with locally higher amounts are likely. Heavy rainfall that occurs is expected to rapidly run off due to fairly wet soil conditions currently in place across central Alabama. Flash flooding will be possible as a result, along with rises on small streams and drainage basins.
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...All of central Alabama, including the following counties, Autauga, Barbour, Bibb, Blount, Bullock, Calhoun, Chambers, Cherokee, Chilton, Clay, Cleburne, Coosa, Dallas, Elmore, Etowah, Fayette, Greene, Hale, Jefferson, Lamar, Lee, Lowndes, Macon, Marengo, Marion, Montgomery, Perry, Pickens, Pike, Randolph, Russell, Shelby, St. Clair, Sumter, Talladega, Tallapoosa, Tuscaloosa, Walker and Winston.
* WHEN...From noon CST today through Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 8 at 4:25AM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
Steady rainfall is expected through much of the daytime today before rain ends tonight. Widespread rainfall amounts up to one inch are expected across northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana, though amounts of 1-2 inches or slightly greater may occur in some locations as well. Dormant vegetation and elevated soil moisture conditions will reduce infiltration and allow for much of this rainfall to runoff into area creeks, streams, and rivers.
Ensemble river forecast guidance indicates the possibility of multiple rivers reaching bankfull due to this rainfall. Urban areas and poor drainage areas may also experience areas of standing water. While widespread flooding is not likely, a few river locations may near flood stage by this weekend.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts, including the possible issuance of Flood Watches, Warnings, and Advisories.
This is expected to be last issuance of this outlook for this event.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cook, IL; DuPage, IL; Ford, IL; Grundy, IL; Iroquois, IL; Kankakee, IL; Kendall, IL; La Salle, IL; Livingston, IL; Will, IL; Benton, IN; Jasper, IN; Lake, IN; Newton, IN; Porter, IN

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 3:08AM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
A disturbance will work together with a backdoor cold front to produce snow showers midday through late tonight along the Continental Divide and spine of the central mountain chain, including the Central Highlands. Snow amounts up to a couple inches may impact the following major travel corridors: US 550 near Cuba, I-25 between Santa Fe and Las Vegas, I-40 from Tijeras Pass through Clines Corners, US 285 near Clines Corners and I-40 near Grants. Short lived difficult driving conditions are likely, but significant improvement is forecast by Saturday morning. More significant snow accumulation is likely above 8,000 ft in the mountains.
For the latest road conditions, dial 511 or 1.800.432.4269, or visit nmroads.com.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Central Highlands; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Sandia/Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Central Highlands; South Central Mountains

cap:parameter.value: ACCUMULATING SNOW TO IMPACT TRAVEL LATE THIS MORNING THROUGH TONIGHT

entry.title: Coastal Flood Watch issued March 8 at 3:52AM EST until March 10 at 3:00PM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways (4.1 to 14.1 feet Mean Lower Low Water).
* WHERE...Portions of eastern, northeastern and southeastern Massachusetts and northern and southern Rhode Island.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some vulnerable coastal roads become impassable around high tide. Flooding 1 to 2 feet deep affects some coastal roads and low lying areas from Revere and Winthrop through Boston to Hull, Braintree, and Quincy. Splashover and debris may wash onto coastal roads when large waves occur. Roads remain passable. Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affect more vulnerable coastal roads alog the North Shore from Salem and Gloucester to Newburyport. Rough surf will likely cause some splashover onto coastal roads around the time of high tide. Roads remain passable. Low lying areas and roads near Nantucket Harbor, including Easy Street, may experience pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep. Minor flooding can be expected across low-lying areas of Newport, Middletown and Portsmouth. Several immediate coastal roads will be impassable for a few hours around time of high tide. Minor beach erosion on the south side of Newport is possible. Roads remain passable. Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affect low lying areas in Provincetown, mainly near the airport and Race Point Road. In Truro, flooding up to one foot deep affects low lying areas near Pamet Harbor and along the Pamet River. Roads remain passable with pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep. This mainly affects low lying areas and roads near Edgartown Harbor, including the Chappy Ferry Dock. Shallow flooding may also approach Five Corners in Vineyard Haven.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Essex; Suffolk; Eastern Norfolk; Eastern Plymouth; Southern Bristol; Southern Plymouth; Barnstable; Dukes; Nantucket; Southeast Providence; Eastern Kent; Bristol; Washington; Newport; Block Island

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:36PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A developing moisture band over the North Pacific will stream northeast and into the panhandle starting mid next week. Rainfall total are looking moderate to heavy with 24 hour totals in the 1 to 2 inch range. The main item to watch is a nose of warmer air will move into the panhandle that will push freezing levels over 5000 feet across the southern panhandle and 1000 to 2000 over the north central panhandle.
The item to keep an eye on is additional snow melt from warming along with the rainfall of the heavier rainfall that stream flow will have higher water levels. We will continue to maintain a watch over this potential hazardous situation.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 1:42PM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A series of storm systems will spread moderate to heavy rainfall across Western Washington this weekend and into early next week. Storm total rainfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches are possible across the Olympic Peninsula. Snow levels near 2500-3000 ft may limit runoff amounts. This amount of prolonged rainfall has the potential to push the Skokomish River into flood stage.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.

cap:parameter.value: THREAT OF RIVER FLOODING SATURDAY EVENING THROUGH TUESDAY FOR MASON COUNTY

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 2:11PM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
A period of steady rainfall is expected to move into the area on Friday, lingering into the evening. Widespread rainfall amounts up to one inch are possible across northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana, with amounts of 1-2 inches possible in isolated areas. Dormant vegetation and elevated soil moisture conditions will reduce infiltration and allow for much of this rainfall to runoff into area streams and rivers.
Ensemble river forecast guidance indicates the possibility of multiple rivers reaching bankfull due to this rainfall. Urban areas and poor drainage areas may also experience areas of standing water. While widespread flooding is not likely, a few river locations may near flood stage by this weekend.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
An update to this outlook will be issued by tomorrow morning.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 7 at 8:01AM CST until March 9 at 7:16AM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Fort Worth TX has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Texas...
Trinity River At Dallas affecting Dallas County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Trinity River at Dallas.
* WHEN...From Friday morning to Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 32.0 feet, Minor flooding of agricultural lands used for cattle grazing will occur. Low water crossings near the river will begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM CST Thursday the stage was 13.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 30.0 feet. - Flood stage is 30.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage tomorrow morning to a crest of 31.3 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 6 at 3:01PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
ESFBIS
Given the recent cold weather, the Missouri River has again been forming ice below Garrison Dam. Thus far, ice has filled the recently cleared portion of the Missouri River from roughly Apple Creek Wildlife Management Area to about three-fourths of a mile upstream of where 12th street southeast turns into Oahe Bend. This would roughly be equal to a little less than five miles of new ice in the river.
The upstream edge of immobile ice as of Wednesday morning was roughly three and a half miles downstream of Fort Abraham Lincoln and Fox Island. While the future rate of ice formation is difficult to predict, forecast overnight lows in the single digits for both Thursday and Friday mornings will continue to encourage ice formation. It should be expected that the upstream edge of continuous ice on the river will migrate upstream. Based on how much ice has already been put in place, it is possible that the upstream edge of continuous ice will reach the Fox Island area before warmer weather enters the area on Friday. By late Saturday, warmer weather will once again reverse this process and start removing ice.
Importantly, pre-ice river levels were about 3.5 feet below that observed prior to last week's ice jam due to already planned lower releases out of Garrison Dam. This suggests that a return to water levels experienced in late February is not likely.

cap:parameter.value: MISSOURI RIVER IS ONCE AGAIN MAKING ICE
